میکن کے دور کے دوران انکشاف ہوا ، اس آیت نے نبی محمد (ص) اور ابتدائی مسلمانوں کو ظلم و ستم کا سامنا کرنا پڑا۔ قریش کے رہنماؤں نے اس کے پیغام کا مذاق اڑایا ، اور یہ فرض کرتے ہوئے کہ ان کی دنیاوی طاقت نے انہیں نتائج سے محفوظ بنا دیا۔ اللہ کے ردعمل نے ان کے تکبر کو ختم کردیا ، اور اس بات کی تصدیق کی کہ اس کا انصاف بے وقت پیمانے پر چلتا ہے ، جو انسان کی بے صبری سے متاثر نہیں ہوتا ہے۔ شیخ تبارسی * مجسما البیان * میں نوٹ کرتے ہیں کہ اس طرح کی آیات اصلاحات کے مواقع فراہم کرنے میں اللہ کی رحمت کو اجاگر کرتی ہیں ، جبکہ غلط کاموں کی منظوری کے طور پر اس کے صبر کی غلط تشریح کے خلاف بھی انتباہ کرتے ہیں۔  

عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت گہرے اسباق پیش کرتی ہے۔ یہ آزمائشوں کے دوران اللہ کی دانشمندی میں اعتماد (*توقکول*) کی تعلیم دیتا ہے ، اور مومنوں کو یاد دلاتا ہے کہ انصاف میں عارضی تاخیر الہی بے حسی کی نشاندہی نہیں کرتی ہے۔ جب ظلم ، بدعنوانی ، یا ذاتی جدوجہد کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے تو ، مسلمانوں کو ثابت قدم رہنے کی تاکید کی جاتی ہے ، اللہ کے منصوبے کو یہ جانتے ہوئے کہ یہ بات بالکل سامنے آرہی ہے۔ اس کے برعکس ، یہ خوشنودی کے خلاف متنبہ کرتا ہے: غلط کام کرنے والوں کے لئے دنیاوی کامیابی تیز تر ہے ، اور احتساب یقینی ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، یہ مصیبتوں میں صبر کو متاثر کرتا ہے ، خود اصلاحات کے لئے وقت کو دانشمندی سے استعمال کرنے کی حوصلہ افزائی کرتا ہے ، اور عارضی طور پر پیش ہونے کی نہیں بلکہ ابدی سچائیوں کے ساتھ کام کرنے کی ضرورت کو تقویت دیتا ہے۔
45.layer2_urdu:
قرآن مجید 68: 45 کے کلاسیکی شیعہ کی توثیق میں ، اسکالرز خدائی حکمت ، انسانی احتساب ، اور خدا کے انصاف کی حتمی فتح کے مابین باہمی مداخلت پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ آیت کا اعلان ، "اور میں ان کو وقت دوں گا۔ بے شک ، میرا منصوبہ مضبوط ہے ،" اللہ کے * ہیکما * (حکمت) اور * 'ADL * (انصاف) کے عینک کے ذریعہ ، شیعہ کے خیال میں مرکزی مذہبی اصولوں کی ترجمانی کی گئی ہے۔ * المزان * میں علامہ تبتابائی نے وضاحت کی ہے کہ جابروں کو مہلت دینا الہی نظرانداز نہیں ہے بلکہ اللہ کی رواداری کا مظہر ہے ، جس سے افراد کو توبہ کرنے یا ان کی بدکاری کا مقابلہ کرنے کا پورا موقع مل جاتا ہے۔ یہ آزاد مرضی (*اختیار*) اور اخلاقی جانچ (*ابٹیلا*) کے بارے میں شیعہ کی تفہیم کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے ، جس میں سزا میں عارضی تاخیر رحمت اور انسانی انتخاب کو کرسٹاللائز کرنے کا ایک ذریعہ بناتی ہے۔

تبریسی کا * مجس البیان * میکن کے دور میں ہی اس آیت کو سیاق و سباق سے دوچار کرتا ہے ، اور یہ نوٹ کرتا ہے کہ اس سے نبیوں اور ابتدائی مسلمانوں کو ان کے ظلم و ستم کے خلاف الہی حمایت کا یقین دلاتا ہے۔ "فرم پلان" (*کیڈ متین*) اللہ کے بدلہ لینے کے ناقابل تسخیر نظام کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جو انسانی تاثرات سے بالاتر ہے۔ شیعہ مبصرین اکثر اس کو * انٹیزر الفراج * (نجات کے منتظر) کے تصور سے جوڑتے ہیں ، جس میں مومنین انصاف کے لئے خدا کے مقرر کردہ ٹائم لائن پر بھروسہ کرتے ہیں ، بشمول مہدی کے حکمرانی کا قیام۔ اس طرح کی تشریحات ظلم اور الہی بدلہ لینے کی یقین کے درمیان صبر (*سبر*) پر شیعہ نظریاتی زور کو تقویت دیتی ہیں۔

آیت بھی شیعہ فقہی اصولوں کے ساتھ ملتی ہے ، جیسا کہ شیخ التوسی جیسے اسکالرز نوٹ کرتے ہیں کہ سزا میں الہی تاخیر روحانی اور معاشرتی دونوں طریقوں سے انصاف کے قیام کی ضرورت پر زور دیتی ہے۔ یہ * الامر بائول-ماؤرف * (اچھ .ا اچھ .ا) کے شیعہ نظارے سے ہم آہنگ ہے ، جہاں ناانصافی کے خلاف عارضی جدوجہد اسکیٹولوجیکل امید سے لازم و ملزوم ہیں۔ اس طرح ، آیت ایک مذہبی تضاد کو گھیرے میں لیتی ہے: الہی رحمت اصلاح کے لئے وقت دیتی ہے ، پھر بھی خدائی انصاف کو یقینی نہیں بناتا ہے کہ کوئی حد سے تجاوز نہیں کی جاسکتی ہے۔
45.layer3_urdu:
عصری شیعہ اسکالرشپ میں ، سورہ القلم کا اعلان * "میں انہیں وقت دوں گا۔ بے شک ، میرا منصوبہ مستحکم ہے" * (68:45) اکثر انسان کی بے صبری کے درمیان خدائی حکمت پر گہری مراقبہ کے طور پر تشریح کیا جاتا ہے۔ آیت اللہ ناصر مکارم شیرازی نے اپنے *طافسیر نمونیہ *میں ، اس بات پر زور دیا ہے کہ غلط کاموں کو سزا دینے میں اللہ کی "تاخیر" بے حسی نہیں بلکہ ایک اسٹریٹجک رحمت ہے۔ یہ اخلاقی نشوونما کے جہت کے طور پر وقت کے بارے میں جدید فلسفیانہ مباحثوں کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے۔ بائونگ-کول ہان جیسے مفکرین آج کے "فوری انصاف" کی ثقافت پر تنقید کرتے ہیں ، اور یہ استدلال کرتے ہیں کہ بامقصد معاشرتی تبدیلی کے لئے اخلاقی عکاسی کی ضرورت ہے ، نہ کہ جلدی فیصلے۔  

ڈاکٹر محمد علی شومالی جیسے جدید اسکالرز اس آیت کو نظامی ناانصافیوں سے مربوط کرتے ہیں۔ اس آیت نے کارکنوں کو یقین دلایا ہے کہ الہی انصاف لکیری ٹائم لائنز سے آگے کام کرتا ہے ، جو ماحولیاتی نظام کے مترادف ہے جہاں تدریجی شفٹوں میں تبدیلی کے نتائج کو دور کیا جاتا ہے۔ طبیعیات دان مظفر اقبال ، قرآنی کے تصورات کو سائنس کے ساتھ مربوط کرتے ہوئے ، نوٹ کرتا ہے کہ کس طرح کائناتی ترتیب (جیسے اینٹروپی یا سیاروں کے چکروں) نے افراتفری اور ڈھانچے کو متوازن کرنے کے لئے ایک "مضبوط منصوبہ" کی عکاسی کی ہے۔  

بین المذاہب مکالمے متوازی کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں: یہودی تعلیمات * ایریک اپیم * (الہی رواداری) اور اسکیوٹولوجیکل انصاف کے عیسائی نظریات دونوں اس قرآنی صبر کی بازگشت کرتے ہیں۔ کثیر الثقافتی سیاق و سباق میں ، آیت انصاف کے متلاشیوں میں یکجہتی کی دعوت دیتی ہے ، فرقہ واریت سے بالاتر ہے۔ عالمی بحرانوں سے ٹکراؤ کرنے والے نوجوانوں کے ل it ، یہ لچک پیش کرتا ہے: کائناتی اخلاقی آرک پر اعتماد ، جبکہ فعال طور پر اس کی تشکیل کرتے ہیں۔ جیسا کہ آیت اللہ جعفر سبھانی نے مشاہدہ کیا ہے ، خدائی "وقت" غیر فعال انتظار نہیں ہے بلکہ اسٹریٹجک ، عقیدے سے جڑوں والی کارروائی کا مطالبہ ہے۔
45.layer4_urdu:
سورہ القلم کی اس گہری آیت میں ، اللہ کا اعلان "میں انہیں وقت دوں گا" احلول بیت کی تعلیمات کے عینک کے ذریعہ سمجھے جانے والے خدائی حکمت کی پرتیں اٹھائے ہوئے ہیں۔ امام علی (ع) *نہج البالاگھا *میں واضح کرتا ہے: "اللہ علیہ السلام کو مہلت دیتا ہے ، لیکن ایک بار جب وہ اسے پکڑتا ہے تو وہ اسے فرار ہونے نہیں دیتا ہے۔" یہ قرآنی اصول کا آئینہ دار ہے کہ سزا میں خدائی تاخیر کمزوری نہیں ہے ، بلکہ روحانی تاثر کا امتحان ہے - توبہ کا ایک موقع جو صرف بیدار ہونے والے ہی کو پہچانتا ہے۔

"میرا منصوبہ مضبوط ہے" (اننا کائڈی متین) کا جملہ اللہ کے کائناتی حکم کے غیر متزلزل محور کے طور پر * امامہ * کی شیعہ تفہیم سے گہری حد تک جڑا ہوا ہے۔ امام جافر السادق (ع) میں کہا گیا ہے کہ: "اللہ کا پختہ منصوبہ زمین پر اس کے ثبوت [ہجاہ] کے ذریعہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے۔ جو بھی ان کے پاس تیزی سے تھامتا ہے وہ اللہ کی رسی کو تیز کرتا ہے۔" یہاں ، "فرم پلان" محض دنیاوی نتائج سے بالاتر ہے - یہ اماموں کے ذریعہ خدائی رہنمائی کی ناقابل تقسیم حقیقت کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جس کا روحانی اختیار (ولیہ) خود تخلیق کو برقرار رکھتا ہے۔

لیڈی فاطمہ (ایس اے) نے سکھایا کہ سچے مومنین تقوا کو کاشت کرنے کے لئے اللہ کے "وقت دینے" کو سمجھتے ہیں ، اور کہا: "عقلمند اس نتائج کو سمجھتا ہے ، جبکہ بے وقوف عارضی لذتوں میں ڈوب جاتا ہے۔" اس طرح یہ آیت خود تشخیص کا آئینہ بن جاتی ہے: کیا ہم اپنا عطا کردہ وقت اماموں کے صاف راستے سے ہم آہنگ ہونے کے لئے استعمال کرتے ہیں ، یا غلطی سے مطمئن ہوجاتے ہیں؟

عملی رہنمائی ابھرتی ہے: 1) اہل بیت کے مشن کے لئے مخلص توبہ اور خدمت کے لئے زندگی کی مہلت کا استعمال کریں 2) اللہ کے منصوبے کے کمال پر اعتماد پر بھی اعتماد جب ناانصافی طویل معلوم ہوتی ہے ، یہ جانتے ہوئے کہ اماموں کو اس کے متین کڈ کا زندہ مجسمہ ہے 3) ہر لمحہ ویلیح سے ہمارے تعلق کا امتحان ہے۔ جیسا کہ امام علی زین الیبدین (ع) *ساہیفا سججدیہ *میں یہ استدلال کرتے ہیں: "مجھے ان لوگوں میں شامل کریں جو آپ کی رہنمائی کی رسی کو پکڑ لیتے ہیں ، جن کے اقدامات آپ کی اطاعت میں پختہ ہیں۔" زندگی کی ٹیمپسٹس کے درمیان اپنی جانوں کو احلول بیت کے صندوق میں لنگر انداز کرنے میں حقیقی مضبوطی ہے۔
45.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Qalam 45, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core theological principles while offering distinct emphases reflective of their intellectual traditions. Classical commentators across traditions, including Tabari and Tabatabai, agree that the verse affirms divine omnipotence and the inevitability of God’s justice, with the phrase “My plan is firm” understood as an assertion of Allah’s unchanging authority over temporal affairs. Sunni scholars like Ibn Kathir and Qurtubi contextualize the “time” granted to disbelievers as a manifestation of divine wisdom (ḥikma), allowing space for repentance while underscoring the inescapability of accountability. This aligns with Shia perspectives in Majma al-Bayan, where Tabrisi similarly notes that respite does not imply divine weakness but rather the perfection of God’s deliberate wisdom.

Divergences emerge in framing the verse’s implications for human agency. Razi’s Mafatih al-Ghayb emphasizes individual moral responsibility, interpreting the delay in punishment as a test of free will—a perspective rooted in Sunni rationalist theology. In contrast, Shia commentaries like Al-Mizan highlight the cosmic dimension of divine planning, with Tabatabai linking the “firm plan” to the Quranic concept of *qadar* (divine decree) as realized through the guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt. Tusi’s At-Tibyan and Qummi’s tafsir further contextualize the verse within historical struggles against oppression, viewing divine patience as preparatory to the ultimate triumph of truth through divinely appointed leadership.

These interpretive variances reflect distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis often prioritizes individual accountability within a communal ethical framework, while Shia readings situate divine planning within a meta-historical narrative of guidance through the Imamate. Both traditions, however, reinforce the Quranic principle that temporal power structures remain subject to Allah’s inviolable justice. Such differences arose organically from early Islamic intellectual history, with Shia hermeneutics developing in dialogue with challenges to legitimate leadership, and Sunni exegesis crystallizing around questions of communal cohesion and individual piety. Neither approach contradicts the verse’s core message but enriches its multidimensional implications for believers’ understanding of divine justice and human perseverance.

45.summary: According to classical exegesis in Tafsir al-Mizan, in *Al-Mizan* explains that granting respite to oppressors is not divine neglect but a manifestation of Allah’s forbearance, allowing individuals full opportunity to repent or compound their misdeeds. In Surah Al-Qalam (68:45), Allah declares, *"Wa umli lahum, inna kaydi mateen"* — "And I will give them time. " This verse addresses the divine wisdom behind Allah’s patience with those who reject truth, emphasizing His ultimate authority and the inevitability of His justice. Classical Shia commentators like Allamah Tabatabai in *Tafsir al-Mizan* explain that *"umli"* (أُمْلِى) derives from *imla’*, meaning to grant respite or delay punishment. Imam Ali (as) elucidates in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "Allah gives the oppressor respite, but once He seizes him, He does not let him escape. Practically, this inspires patience in adversity, encourages using time wisely for self-reform, and reinforces the need to align actions with eternal truths, not transient appearances.

46.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qalam (68:46), Allah addresses the accusations made by the Quraysh against Prophet Muhammad (pbuh), who claimed he sought material gain through his prophethood. The verse challenges them: *"Am tas’aluhum ajran fa-hum min maghramin muthqaloon?"* (Do you ask them for payment, so they are burdened by debt?). Here, *ajr* refers to a worldly reward or compensation, while *maghram* denotes a crushing financial obligation. The rhetorical question exposes the absurdity of their claims—the Prophet never demanded wealth for delivering Allah’s message, yet his opponents framed his mission as a transactional scheme to discredit him.

Historically, this verse reflects the Meccan elite’s resistance to Islam’s moral reforms, which threatened their social and economic dominance. They mocked the Prophet’s lack of interest in wealth, asking why he didn’t accept riches if he were truly a prophet (as seen in other verses like 6:90). The Quran repeatedly emphasizes the Prophets’ detachment from material gain, a theme echoed in Shia tafsir by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai, who notes that divine guides (*hudat*) like Muhammad (pbuh) and the Ahlul Bayt (as) reject worldly compensation, seeking only spiritual rewards (*ajr al-akhira*).

For contemporary Muslims, this verse underscores the purity of intention required in religious leadership and daily acts of faith. It condemns exploiting religious platforms for profit or power, urging believers to embody selflessness. In a world where materialism often distorts spiritual pursuits, this verse reminds us to serve Allah and humanity without hidden agendas, aligning with Imam Ali’s (as) teaching: *"The worth of a man is according to his courage, his truthfulness according to his balance of character."* True faith, like the Prophet’s mission, is a gift—not a transaction.
46.layer2:
In Surah al-Qalam (68:46), the Divine rebuttal to Meccan accusations against the Prophet Muhammad (ṣ) is framed as a rhetorical question exposing the absurdity of claims that he sought material gain from his mission. Classical Shia exegetes, including Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, contextualize this verse within the Quraysh’s persistent slander that the Prophet demanded compensation for his message. Tabrisi emphasizes that the verse’s interrogative form (“Or do you ask them a payment?”) constitutes a definitive negation, as the Prophet’s entire life exemplified rejection of worldly recompense for divine truth. This aligns with the Shia theological principle of *ismah* (divinely granted infallibility), which ensures prophets and Imams transcend base motivations.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as), as cited in classical sources, elucidates that the verse underscores the disbelievers’ spiritual bankruptcy: their fixation on “burdening debt” metaphorically represents their incapacity to perceive prophethood as a divine gift rather than a transactional exchange. Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* expands this into a cosmic principle: just as the Prophet sought no reward from creation, the Ahlul Bayt’s guardianship (*wilayah*) operates as a selfless divine bounty (*lutf*), obliging gratitude rather than financial liability. This theological framework rejects any commodification of guidance, affirming that true leadership in Islam—whether prophetic or Imamic—is rooted in transcendent responsibility, not worldly negotiation.

The verse also implicitly critiques power structures that reduce spiritual authority to economic transactions, a theme recurrent in Shia critiques of corrupt caliphal regimes. Jurisprudentially, this reinforces the Shia position that religious leadership must remain untainted by material exploitation, mirroring the Prophet’s and Imams’ detachment—a cornerstone of Twelver ethics. Thus, the verse transcends its historical context to affirm a perennial principle: divine guidance is a grace, never a debt.
46.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars approach Surah Al-Qalam 46 as a profound critique of transactional spirituality and exploitative systems. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis *Tafsir Nemooneh*, frames this verse as Allah’s defence of Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) against accusations of seeking material gain for delivering divine guidance. The rhetorical question—“Or do you ask them for payment?”—highlights the Prophet’s selflessness, contrasting with today’s commodification of religious authority or predatory capitalism.  

Modern thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this verse to ethical economics, noting its resonance with critiques of debt slavery and systemic inequality. The “burden” of debt (maghram) mirrors contemporary crises—from student loans trapping youth to microfinance exploitation in the Global South. Philosopher Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi extends this to interpersonal ethics, arguing that the verse condemns relationships reduced to transactional exchanges, urging societies to prioritise empathy over profit.  

Scientifically, behavioural economics reveals how debt stress impairs decision-making and mental health, aligning with the Quranic warning against burdens that “weigh down” the soul. Socially, the verse challenges neoliberal models that prioritise profit over human dignity, urging faith communities to advocate for fair wages and debt relief as acts of worship.  

Interfaith parallels emerge in Pope Francis’ critiques of “economy that kills” and Buddhist teachings on right livelihood. This universality underscores Islam’s call for systemic justice beyond Muslim contexts. In multicultural societies, the verse invites interreligious solidarity against exploitative structures, framing economic equity as a shared spiritual imperative.  

Ultimately, this verse becomes a manifesto for integrity in leadership and economic justice—a timeless reminder that truth cannot be commodified, and compassion must outweigh calculation.
46.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah Al-Qalam, Allah addresses those who accuse the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) of seeking worldly gain through his divine mission. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this verse transcends its apparent context, unveiling profound truths about the nature of spiritual leadership and the obligation of Wilayah (divine guardianship). Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi* that the “payment” mentioned here symbolizes the recognition of the Prophet’s true station and the acceptance of the Imams’ divine authority. The Prophet’s “reward” was never material; it was the love and loyalty owed to his purified progeny, as stated in the Quran: *"Say, I ask no reward for it except love for [my] near kin"* (42:23).  

The verse warns against those who perceive divine guidance as a transactional burden rather than a liberating truth. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, *“The world is a burden to those who reject the Wilayah of the Ahlul Bayt, but for the believers, it is a bridge to the Hereafter”* (Nahj al-Balagha). The “debt” here signifies the spiritual poverty of denying the Imamah, for true enrichment lies in submitting to the divinely appointed guides. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized this in her sermon: *“Allah made obedience to us the foundation of His religion and love for us the pillar of His faith”* (Bihar al-Anwar).  

Practically, this verse invites believers to purify their intentions, detach from materialistic motives in worship, and embrace the Imams’ teachings as the ultimate spiritual wealth. To be “burdened down” is to resist the light of Wilayah; to be uplifted is to anchor one’s soul in the love and obedience of the Ahlul Bayt, whose guidance is the only path to divine proximity.

سورہ القلم کی برائٹ آیت میں ، اللہ ان لوگوں سے خطاب کرتا ہے جو حضرت محمد صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم پر الزام لگاتے ہیں کہ وہ اپنے الہی مشن کے ذریعے دنیاوی فائدہ حاصل کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتے ہیں۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن ہے) یہ سکھاتا ہے کہ یہ آیت اپنے واضح سیاق و سباق سے بالاتر ہے ، روحانی قیادت کی نوعیت اور ولیہ (الہی سرپرستی) کی ذمہ داری کے بارے میں گہری سچائیوں کی نقاب کشائی کرتی ہے۔ امام جافر السادق (اس پر امن ہے) * طافسیر الکوومی * میں وضاحت کرتے ہیں کہ یہاں ذکر کردہ "ادائیگی" نبی کے حقیقی اسٹیشن کی پہچان اور اماموں کے الہی اختیار کی قبولیت کی علامت ہے۔ نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم کبھی بھی مادی نہیں تھا۔ یہ اس کی پاکیزگی اور وفاداری تھی جو اس کی پاکیزہ اولاد سے واجب الادا تھی ، جیسا کہ قرآن مجید میں کہا گیا ہے: * "کہو ، میں اس کے لئے کوئی انعام نہیں دیتا سوائے اس کے کہ [میرے] رشتہ داروں کے قریب" * (42:23)۔  

آیت میں ان لوگوں کے خلاف متنبہ کیا گیا ہے جو الہی رہنمائی کو آزادانہ سچائی کے بجائے لین دین کے بوجھ کے طور پر سمجھتے ہیں۔ امام علی (اس پر امن) نے سکھایا ، * "دنیا ان لوگوں کے لئے ایک بوجھ ہے جو اہل بیت کے ولیہ کو مسترد کرتے ہیں ، لیکن مومنین کے لئے ، یہ اس کے بعد ایک پل ہے" * (ناہج البالھا)۔ یہاں کا "قرض" امامہ سے انکار کرنے کی روحانی غربت کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، کیونکہ حقیقی افزودگی خدائی مقرر کردہ رہنماؤں کو پیش کرنے میں ہے۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن) نے اپنے خطبے میں اس پر زور دیا: * "اللہ نے ہمارے مذہب کی بنیاد اور اپنے عقیدے کا ستون ہمارے لئے محبت کی بنیاد رکھی" * (بہار الانور)۔  

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنین کو دعوت دیتی ہے کہ وہ اپنے ارادوں کو پاک کریں ، عبادت میں مادیت پسندانہ مقاصد سے الگ ہوجائیں ، اور آخری روحانی دولت کے طور پر ائمہ کی تعلیمات کو گلے لگائیں۔ "بوجھ ڈاون" ہونا ولیاہ کی روشنی کا مقابلہ کرنا ہے۔ ترقی یافتہ ہونا یہ ہے کہ کسی کی روح کو اہل بائٹ کی محبت اور اطاعت میں لنگر انداز کرنا ہے ، جس کی رہنمائی خدائی قربت کا واحد راستہ ہے۔
46.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Qalam 68:46, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s core rhetorical purpose: to refute accusations that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) sought material gain through his prophethood. Sunni commentators like Tabari and Ibn Kathir contextualise the verse within Meccan opposition, where tribal leaders alleged the Prophet aimed to profit from his message. Ibn Kathir emphasises the Qur’anic rebuttal of such claims, stressing the Prophet’s selflessness as integral to his moral authority. Similarly, Shia scholars such as Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) affirm that the verse underscores the purity of divine messengers, with Tabatabai noting that demanding worldly compensation would contradict the essence of prophethood (nubuwwa) as a divine trust.

Divergences emerge in theological extensions. Sunni exegetes like Qurtubi and Razi focus on the verse’s universal lesson against conflating spiritual guidance with material transactions, often linking it to broader ethical injunctions. Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) frames it as a critique of human tendencies to distrust selfless leadership. In contrast, Shia sources like Tusi (At-Tibyan) and Qummi (Tafsir al-Qummi) connect the verse to the Imamah doctrine, interpreting the “payment” metaphor as rejecting worldly compromises in spiritual leadership. Qummi alludes to parallels with the Ahl al-Bayt’s rejection of political bribes, embedding the verse within Shia narratives of divinely ordained stewardship.

These differences reflect distinct theological frameworks: Sunni interpretations prioritise the Prophet’s personal example, while Shia readings extend the principle to their Imams. Historically, such variations stem from early debates over religious authority post-Prophet, with Shia thought emphasising continuity through infallible guides. Both traditions, however, reinforce the centrality of sincerity in religious practice, urging believers to emulate prophetic detachment from materialism. The verse thus remains a unifying ethical touchstone, even as its exegetical applications illuminate the rich diversity of Islamic thought.

In Surah Al-Qalam (68:46), Allah addresses the accusations made by the Quraysh against Prophet Muhammad (pbuh), who claimed he sought material gain through his prophethood. The verse challenges them: *"Am tas’aluhum ajran fa-hum min maghramin muthqaloon?"* (Do you ask them for payment, so they are burdened by debt?). Here, *ajr* refers to a worldly reward or compensation, while *maghram* denotes a crushing financial obligation. 47.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qalam (68:47), Allah challenges those who rejected Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) by asking: *"Am indahumul-ghaybu fahum yaktuboon"* (Or have they [knowledge of] the unseen, so they write [it] down?). This verse exposes the arrogance of the Quraysh leaders in Mecca who dismissed divine revelation while claiming superior wisdom. The rhetorical question mocks their false sense of authority – how could they possess *ghayb* (hidden knowledge), a quality exclusive to Allah and those He chooses to inform, like prophets and divinely guided Imams?  

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allama Tabatabai's *Al-Mizan*, explains that *ghayb* here refers to knowledge beyond human perception – past/future events, divine decrees, and spiritual truths. The verb *yaktuboon* (they write) implies documenting such knowledge systematically, a capacity the pagans lacked. Historically, this verse countered claims by Arab soothsayers (*kahin*) who pretended to access hidden realms through jinn, contrasting their fragmented "revelations" with the Quran's coherent, transformative message.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse warns against seeking or trusting unauthorized sources of *ghayb* – whether through astrology, occult practices, or pseudo-spiritual influencers claiming secret knowledge. It reaffirms that true understanding of the unseen comes only through Allah’s chosen channels: the Quran, the Prophet’s (pbuh) teachings, and the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt (as), whom Shia tradition holds as inheritors of prophetic knowledge. Practically, this encourages reliance on authenticated divine sources rather than superstitions or unverified claims, while humbly accepting that ultimate knowledge rests with Allah. As Imam Ali (as) stated, "Knowledge is a trust – take it from its people," reminding believers to align their pursuit of truth with divinely guided authorities.
47.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qalam (68:47), the rhetorical question "Or have they [knowledge of] the unseen, so they write [it] down?" challenges the Meccan polytheists’ pretensions to divine knowledge while rejecting Prophet Muhammad’s (ṣ) revelation. Classical Shia exegetes emphasise this verse’s theological implications regarding the exclusive divine authority over *ghayb* (the unseen), a concept central to Shia cosmology. 

Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* interprets this as a categorical negation of any human claim to independent knowledge of the metaphysical realm, asserting that *ghayb* belongs solely to Allah. He notes that while prophets and divinely appointed Imams receive *selected* knowledge of the unseen through divine bestowal (*ta‘yīd*), this is fundamentally distinct from intrinsic possession or autonomous comprehension. The verse thus condemns the Quraysh’s arrogant dismissal of revelation while implicitly affirming the necessity of prophetic and Imamic guidance as channels of divine wisdom.

Shaykh Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* contextualises this within the broader Quranic discourse on prophethood, observing that the disbelievers’ rejection stemmed from their materialist worldview denying transcendental realities. The rhetorical force of "do they write it?" underscores the absurdity of attributing prescience to those lacking celestial authorization. This aligns with Shia doctrines of *ismah (infallibility) and *nass* (divine designation), which reserve access to *ghayb* for the *ma‘sumin* (infallibles) as custodians of esoteric knowledge.

The verse also reinforces the Shia epistemological principle that true understanding of the unseen – whether cosmological, eschatological, or legislative – flows exclusively through divinely sanctioned authorities. This underpins the Shia position on the necessity of Imamah as an extension of prophethood in preserving and interpreting revelation. As articulated in traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (a), the Ahlul Bayt’s knowledge of the unseen, mediated through divine will, stands in stark contrast to human conjecture, thereby validating their role as the *ḥujjah* (proof) of Allah upon creation.
47.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qalam’s rhetorical question — *“Or do they possess the unseen, so they write it down?”* — is interpreted as a timeless critique of human arrogance in claiming absolute knowledge. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasizes that the verse challenges materialist worldviews that reduce reality to empirically measurable phenomena, ignoring metaphysical truths (ghayb) known only to Allah and those He permits, such as the Prophet and Ahlul Bayt. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to today’s “post-truth” era, where misinformation and ideological certitude often masquerade as infallible knowledge, whether in politics, science, or social media. The verse, he argues, invites humility: just as 7th-century opponents of the Prophet falsely claimed authority, modern societies must recognize the limits of human understanding.  

Scientifically, the verse resonates with quantum physics’ acknowledgment of uncertainty and dark matter — phenomena beyond direct observation. Philosophically, it aligns with critiques of positivism, as scholars like Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah note: “Our age of AI and big data still cannot predict a heartbeat’s timing; how then can we claim mastery over destiny?” Socially, this verse critiques systems — from exploitative capitalism to authoritarian regimes — that claim omniscience while ignoring ethical or ecological consequences.  

Interfaith dialogues highlight parallels: Jewish mysticism (Kabbalah’s *sitra achra*) and Hindu *maya* similarly caution against mistaking the visible for the ultimate reality. For multicultural societies, the verse becomes a call to epistemic modesty — recognizing that diverse spiritual and cultural traditions hold partial truths, but ultimate knowledge (ghayb) remains divine. In an era of climate crisis and AI ethics, this verse reminds humanity to balance innovation with reverence for the unseen dimensions of existence.
47.layer4:
In Surah Al-Qalam, verse 47, Allah challenges those who arrogantly claim authority over divine truths: *"Or have they [knowledge of] the unseen, so they write [it] down?"* The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) illuminate this verse as a profound reminder of humanity’s dependence on divine guidance and the exclusive right of Allah to grant knowledge of the unseen (ghayb) to His chosen representatives. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in Nahj al-Balagha: *"The unseen is known only to Allah, but He makes some of it known to His angels, His prophets, and His proofs [the Imams]."* This establishes that true knowledge of ghayb flows solely through the channel of Wilayah (divine guardianship) bestowed upon the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his purified progeny.

Imam Jafar as-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains that this verse exposes the futility of human intellect or worldly systems claiming mastery over spiritual realities. The Imams, as inheritors of the Prophet’s wisdom, teach that authentic knowledge of the unseen is not acquired through speculation but received as a divine trust (amanah) for guiding humanity. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasizes this in her sermon: *"Allah made obedience to us the order of His creation and our Wilayah protection for the nations."* Thus, recognizing the Imamah as the sole source of illuminated knowledge becomes an act of spiritual awakening.

Practically, this verse calls believers to humility and reliance on the Ahlul Bayt. Spiritual development lies in seeking nearness to them through adherence to their teachings, supplications like Dua al-Tawassul, and studying their narrations. As Imam Ali al-Ridha (peace be upon him) taught: *"Whoever seeks knowledge from other than us will perish."* By anchoring our hearts to their eternal light, we transcend limited perceptions and align with the true scribes of divine wisdom.

عصری مسلمانوں کے ل this ، یہ آیت * غئی بی * کے غیر مجاز ذرائع کی تلاش یا ان پر اعتماد کرنے کے خلاف انتباہ کرتی ہے-چاہے وہ نجومیات ، جادوئی طریقوں ، یا خفیہ علم کے دعوے کرنے والے چھدم روحانی اثر و رسوخ کے ذریعہ۔ اس کی تصدیق کی گئی ہے کہ غیب کے بارے میں حقیقی تفہیم صرف اللہ کے منتخب کردہ چینلز کے ذریعہ آتی ہے: قرآن ، نبی کی (صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم) کی تعلیمات ، اور اہل بیت (ع) کی رہنمائی ، جسے شیعہ روایت پیشن گوئی کے علم کے وراثت میں رکھتی ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، اس سے توہم پرستی یا غیر تصدیق شدہ دعووں کی بجائے مستند الہی ذرائع پر انحصار کی حوصلہ افزائی ہوتی ہے ، جبکہ عاجزی کے ساتھ یہ قبول کرتے ہیں کہ حتمی علم اللہ کے ساتھ ہے۔ جیسا کہ امام علی (ع) نے کہا ، "علم ایک اعتماد ہے - اسے اپنے لوگوں سے لے لو ،" مومنوں کو یاد دلاتا ہے کہ وہ خدائی رہنمائی کرنے والے حکام کے ساتھ سچائی کے حصول کو سیدھ میں لائیں۔

47.layer5:
In interpreting Q68:47, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s core rhetorical challenge to the Prophet’s opponents, who denied revelation while making baseless claims. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) both contextualize this verse within Meccan debates, where polytheists dismissed Muhammad’s prophethood yet lacked any coherent alternative explanation for the Quran’s divine origin. The consensus across traditions, as seen in Ibn Kathir and al-Tusi, affirms that knowledge of the unseen (ghayb) belongs solely to God, negating human capacity to access it independently—a theological principle enshrined in Quranic verses like 72:26-27.

Divergences emerge in extrapolating the nature of "writing down" the unseen. Sunni commentators like al-Qurtubi and al-Razi focus on the verse’s literal critique of pre-Islamic soothsayers (kuhhan), interpreting "they write" as referring to fabricated predictions. This aligns with their broader emphasis on protecting prophethood’s uniqueness against contemporary challengers. Shia scholars, while acknowledging this historical layer, often expand the interpretation through the lens of Imamology. Al-Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* argues the verse implicitly affirms that true knowledge of ghayb—when recorded—must derive from divine designation, a quality later extended to the Ahl al-Bayt. Al-Qummi’s tafsir similarly links the verse to the Imams’ inherited knowledge, though without contradicting the Sunni position on prophethood’s exclusivity.

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis prioritizes safeguarding the Prophet’s singular role, while Shia readings view the Imams as legitimate inheritors of prophetic knowledge. Practically, this influences concepts of religious authority, with Shia tradition valuing the Imams’ teachings as extensions of divine wisdom, whereas Sunni thought emphasizes direct reliance on Quran and authenticated Sunnah. Historically, these interpretations developed through each tradition’s engagement with their respective canonical sources and early community challenges, reflecting complementary rather than contradictory approaches to Quranic hermeneutics.

یہ اختلافات الگ الگ مذہبی فریم ورک سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں: سنی کی اصلاح نبی کے واحد کردار کی حفاظت کو ترجیح دیتی ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ ریڈنگ اماموں کو پیشن گوئی کے علم کے جائز وراثت کے طور پر دیکھتی ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، اس سے مذہبی اتھارٹی کے تصورات کو متاثر کیا جاتا ہے ، شیعہ روایت کے ساتھ ہی اماموں کی تعلیمات کو خدائی حکمت کی توسیع کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے ، جبکہ سنی سوچ قرآن پر براہ راست انحصار پر زور دیتا ہے اور تصدیق شدہ سنت پر۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ تشریحات ہر روایت کی ان کے متعلقہ مکروہ ذرائع اور ابتدائی معاشرتی چیلنجوں کے ساتھ مشغولیت کے ذریعہ تیار کی گئیں ، جو قرآنی ہرمینیٹکس کے متضاد نقطہ نظر کی بجائے تکمیلی کی عکاسی کرتی ہیں۔

48.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qalam, verse 48, Allah instructs Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) to remain steadfast in awaiting divine judgment, using the story of Prophet Yunus (Jonah) as a cautionary example. The verse begins with *faṣbir liḥukmi rabbika* ("be patient for your Lord’s decree"), emphasizing trust in Allah’s timing and wisdom. The phrase *wa lā takun kaṣāḥibi l-ḥūt* ("do not be like the companion of the fish") refers to Yunus, who is called *ṣāḥib al-ḥūt* (companion of the whale) due to his ordeal of being swallowed after abandoning his mission prematurely. The verse highlights Yunus’s moment of anguish (*huwa makẓūm*), a term denoting suppressed grief or stifled despair, reflecting his emotional state when he called out to Allah from the darkness of the fish’s belly.

This verse was revealed during the Meccan period, when the Prophet faced intense persecution and rejection. By referencing Yunus, Allah reassures Muhammad (pbuh) that even prophets face trials but must avoid impulsive reactions. Shia tafsir, as explained by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai, underscores that Yunus’s mistake lay in losing patience and departing his people without explicit divine permission, leading to his temporary isolation. His eventual redemption through sincere supplication (*dua*) in Surah Al-Anbiya (21:87) demonstrates Allah’s mercy for those who repent.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse teaches the necessity of *sabr* (patient perseverance) amid adversity. It warns against abandoning responsibilities or losing hope during hardship, urging believers to trust Allah’s plan rather than act rashly. In Shia tradition, this aligns with the ethos of the Ahlul Bayt, particularly Imam Ali’s teachings on enduring injustice with dignity. Practically, it encourages Muslims to seek solace in prayer during distress, avoid despair, and remain committed to their duties—whether in personal struggles, social challenges, or spiritual growth—knowing divine relief follows sincere patience.
48.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qalam verse 48, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) to maintain steadfast patience in awaiting divine judgment, drawing a cautionary parallel to the "companion of the fish" — a reference to Prophet Yunus (Jonah). Classical Shia exegetes, including Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* and Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, elucidate this verse by emphasising the theological necessity of *sabr* (patient perseverance) as a prophetic virtue and a marker of spiritual maturity. The admonition against resembling Yunus in his moment of distress is interpreted not as a condemnation of the prophet himself — for Shia theology upholds the infallibility (*ismah*) of all prophets — but as a warning against the emotional state of haste and despair that momentarily overtook him.

Tabrisi explains that Yunus’s "distress" (*makzum*) arose when he abandoned his mission to Nineveh prematurely, frustrated by his people’s initial rejection, before receiving explicit divine permission to depart. His subsequent entrapment within the fish symbolises the spiritual constriction that follows impatience with divine decree (*qada*). Tabatabai expands this analysis, noting that Yunus’s cry from the fish’s belly ("There is no god but You! Glory be to You! I have been among the wrongdoers," Quran 21:87) exemplifies the transformative power of repentance (*tawbah*) and reliance on Allah’s mercy — a redemption underscoring the Shi’i principle that divine forgiveness is inseparable from sincere return to God.

The verse’s directive to the Prophet Muhammad carries profound implications for Shia imamology. Just as prophetic patience embodies trust in Allah’s wisdom, the Imams from the Ahl al-Bayt — as inheritors of prophetic stewardship — exemplified this virtue amidst persecution, modelling the necessity of enduring temporal trials while awaiting divine justice. This theological framework reinforces the Shia jurisprudential emphasis on *intizar al-faraj* (awaiting deliverance), where patient adherence to divine law during occultation becomes an act of spiritual and political fidelity. Thus, the verse transcends historical narrative, offering a perennial lesson on the alignment of human will with divine *hukm* (command), a cornerstone of Shia existential and ethical philosophy.
48.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qalam 48 is often interpreted as a profound call to *strategic patience* amid adversity, emphasizing trust in divine wisdom over reactive despair. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis, notes that Prophet Yunus’s (Jonah) distress inside the fish symbolizes the human tendency to seek immediate relief from crises, while the verse urges believers to embrace disciplined endurance as a form of spiritual and intellectual maturity. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to resilience in facing systemic injustices—from political oppression to climate crises—where impulsive reactions risk undermining long-term solutions.  

Neuroscientific insights into stress management align with this ethos: studies on mindfulness (e.g., Dr. Richard Davidson’s work) show that patient, intentional responses rewire the brain toward emotional regulation, mirroring the Quranic ideal of *sabr* (perseverance). Socially, the verse critiques today’s “instant gratification” culture, where viral outrage often eclipses thoughtful activism. Philosophers like Dr. Mostafa Malekian frame Yunus’s story as a warning against letting anguish cloud ethical judgment—a lesson for movements addressing wars or inequality, where haste can perpetuate cycles of harm.  

Interfaith parallels emerge in Christian and Jewish traditions that venerate Jonah’s repentance, highlighting shared values in transcultural struggles. For Shia communities, this verse resonates in contexts like the ongoing plight of Palestinians or Rohingya Muslims, where patience is neither passivity nor surrender but a commitment to principled, sustained struggle (*jihad al-nafs*). Ultimately, the verse bridges seventh-century wisdom and 21st-century challenges, advocating a balance between urgency and wisdom—a roadmap for navigating our fractured world with faith and foresight.
48.layer4:
The verse calls the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) to unwavering patience in awaiting divine decree, contrasting his mission with the momentary lapse of Prophet Yunus (peace be upon him), who cried out in anguish while "constrained" (makzoom) within the fish. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this verse transcends historical narrative, offering timeless guidance on spiritual fortitude through attachment to *Wilayah* (divine guardianship).  

Imam Sadiq (peace be upon him) states in *Tafsir al-Qummi*: "The distress of Yunus was not from the fish, but from the darkness of separation – he acted before the command of his Lord was manifest." This refers to Yunus leaving his people without explicit divine permission, symbolizing impatience with divine timing. The Prophet Muhammad is thus instructed to embody perfect *sabr* (patience) rooted in trust (*tawakkul*), knowing Allah’s plan unfolds through the channel of *Imamah*.  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) illuminates this in her sermon: "Patience is the lamp of the heart... its fuel is submission to the *Wali* of Allah." True patience, then, is not passive endurance but active alignment with the Imam’s guidance. When trials arise – whether personal crises or the occultation of the Imam – the believer must avoid "calling out" in despair like Yunus, but instead anchor themselves in the rope of *Wilayah*.  

Imam Baqir (peace be upon him) advises: "When tribulations surround you like darkness, turn to the *Hujjah* [the Imam] as Yunus turned to His Lord from the layers of the sea." Practically, this means seeking solutions through supplications taught by the Imams (e.g., Dua Faraj), studying their teachings, and maintaining spiritual connection during hardship. The verse thus becomes a mirror: our trials test not our suffering, but our fidelity to the *Ahlul Bayt*’s path amidst the storm.

یہ آیت میکن کے دور میں سامنے آئی تھی ، جب نبی کو شدید ظلم و ستم اور مسترد ہونے کا سامنا کرنا پڑا تھا۔ یونس کا حوالہ دے کر ، اللہ نے محمد (صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم) کو یقین دلایا کہ نبیوں کو بھی آزمائشوں کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے لیکن اسے لازمی رد عمل سے بچنا چاہئے۔ شیعہ طافسیر ، جیسا کہ الامہ تبتابائی جیسے اسکالرز نے سمجھایا ہے ، اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے کہ یونس کی غلطی صبر سے محروم ہونے اور اپنے لوگوں کو واضح الہی اجازت کے بغیر رخصت کرنے میں ہے ، جس کی وجہ سے اس کی عارضی تنہائی ہوتی ہے۔ سورہ الانبیہ (21:87) میں مخلصانہ التجا (*دعا*) کے ذریعہ ان کی حتمی چھٹکارا ان لوگوں کے لئے اللہ کی رحمت کا مظاہرہ کرتی ہے جو توبہ کرتے ہیں۔

عصری مسلمانوں کے ل this ، یہ آیت مشکلات کے درمیان * صابر * (مریض استقامت) کی ضرورت کی تعلیم دیتی ہے۔ اس نے ذمہ داریوں کو ترک کرنے یا مشکلات کے دوران امید سے محروم ہونے کے خلاف متنبہ کیا ہے ، مومنین پر زور دیا ہے کہ وہ جلدی سے کام کرنے کی بجائے اللہ کے منصوبے پر اعتماد کریں۔ شیعہ روایت میں ، یہ اہل بیت کے اخلاق ، خاص طور پر امام علی کی وقار کے ساتھ ناانصافی برداشت کرنے کی تعلیمات کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، یہ مسلمانوں کو حوصلہ افزائی کرتا ہے کہ وہ پریشانی کے دوران نماز میں سکون حاصل کریں ، مایوسی سے بچیں ، اور اپنے فرائض کے لئے پرعزم رہیں - چاہے ذاتی جدوجہد ، معاشرتی چیلنجوں ، یا روحانی نشوونما میں - خدائی امداد کو جاننے سے مخلص صبر کی پیروی ہوتی ہے۔

تبریسی نے وضاحت کی ہے کہ یونس کی "پریشانی" (*مکزم*) اس وقت پیدا ہوئی جب اس نے اپنے مشن کو وقت سے پہلے ہی نینوا کے پاس چھوڑ دیا ، اس سے قبل اپنے لوگوں کے ابتدائی مسترد ہونے سے مایوسی ہوئی ، اس سے پہلے کہ جانے کی واضح الہی اجازت حاصل ہو۔ مچھلی کے اندر اس کے بعد کا الجھاؤ روحانی مجبوری کی علامت ہے جو خدائی فرمان (*قادا*) کے ساتھ بے صبری کی پیروی کرتا ہے۔ تبتابائی نے اس تجزیے کو وسعت دی ، یہ نوٹ کرتے ہوئے کہ مچھلی کے پیٹ سے یونس کا رونا ("آپ کے سوا کوئی خدا نہیں ہے! آپ کی شان! میں غلط لوگوں میں شامل رہا ہوں ،" قرآن 21:87) توبہ کی تبدیلی کی طاقت کی مثال دیتا ہے (*توبہ*) اور اللہ کی رحمت پر انحصار کرتا ہے۔ خدا کی طرف لوٹنا۔

48.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 68:48, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s core message: a divine admonition to Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) to exercise patience in adversity, contrasting his steadfastness with Prophet Yunus’s (Jonah) momentary lapse in distress. Classical Sunni commentators like Tabari and Ibn Kathir contextualise Yunus’s story as a universal lesson on trusting divine wisdom, emphasising that even prophets are tested. Similarly, Shia scholars such as Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) affirm this moral, noting that Yunus’s “call in darkness” (Quran 21:87) exemplifies sincere repentance, validating Allah’s mercy. Both traditions agree the verse underscores the necessity of *sabr* (patience) as a prophetic virtue and a model for believers.

Divergences emerge in theological nuances. Sunni scholars like Qurtubi and Razi focus on Yunus’s accountability for leaving his mission prematurely, interpreting his distress as a human lapse mitigated by Allah’s forgiveness. In contrast, Shia sources like Tusi (At-Tibyan) and Qummi highlight Yunus’s *makzum* (suppressed anguish) as a metaphor for resisting oppression, subtly linking it to the Ahlul Bayt’s trials. Tabatabai further posits that Yunus’s hasty prayer arose not from doubt but from overwhelming emotion, distinguishing between prophetic infallibility (*ismah*) and human emotional responses—a perspective less emphasised in Sunni works.

These distinctions reflect broader hermeneutical frameworks. Sunni exegesis often prioritises individual moral accountability, while Shia readings integrate historical narratives of the Imams’ suffering. Such differences, however, remain pedagogical rather than dogmatic, reinforcing shared ethical principles. Historically, Shia emphasis on the Ahlul Bayt’s patience under persecution and Sunni focus on communal resilience during early Islamic crises shaped these interpretive trajectories, yet both traditions ultimately unite in viewing the verse as a timeless call to spiritual fortitude.

In Surah Al-Qalam, verse 48, Allah instructs Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) to remain steadfast in awaiting divine judgment, using the story of Prophet Yunus (Jonah) as a cautionary example. The verse begins with *faṣbir liḥukmi rabbika* ("be patient for your Lord’s decree"), emphasizing trust in Allah’s timing and wisdom. The phrase *wa lā takun kaṣāḥibi l-ḥūt* ("do not be like the companion of the fish") refers to Yunus, who is called *ṣāḥib al-ḥūt* (companion of the whale) due to his ordeal of being swallowed after abandoning his mission prematurely. Imam Sadiq (peace be upon him) states in *Tafsir al-Qummi*: "The distress of Yunus was not from the fish, but from the darkness of separation – he acted before the command of his Lord was manifest. this verse teaches the necessity of *sabr* (patient perseverance) amid adversity.

49.layer1:
This verse from Surah Al-Qalam refers to Prophet Yunus (Jonah), who faced a profound trial after leaving his people in frustration when they initially rejected his message. The phrase *lawlā an tadārakahu ni’matun min rabbihi* ("If not that a favor from his Lord overtook him") highlights Allah’s swift mercy intervening to save Yunus from being cast onto *al-‘arā’* (a barren, exposed shore) in a state of disgrace (*madhmun*). The *ni’mah* (divine favor) here refers to Yunus being spared by the whale’s protection and eventual forgiveness after his sincere repentance in the depths of the sea, as narrated in other Quranic passages (e.g., Surah As-Saffat 37:143–144).  

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes that even prophets are tested, and divine grace is inseparable from sincere accountability. The word *tadārakahu* (overtook) underscores how Allah’s mercy actively pursues those who turn to Him, even amid errors. Historically, this verse reassures believers that despair is never final—Yunus’s story teaches that sincere *tawbah* (repentance) and trust in Allah’s plan can transform crises into redemption.  

In modern life, this verse reminds Muslims to avoid impulsive reactions to hardship and to trust in Allah’s timing. When faced with failure or criticism, the lesson is to seek refuge in humility and patience, recognizing that Allah’s mercy can uplift us from the lowest moments. It also cautions against judging others harshly, as even a prophet faced human struggles. By internalizing Yunus’s journey—acknowledging mistakes, seeking forgiveness, and relying on divine grace—we cultivate resilience and hope, knowing no soul is beyond the reach of Allah’s compassion.
49.layer2:
In classical Shia exegesis of Quran 68:49, commentators emphasize the interplay between divine grace (*lutf*) and human accountability, contextualizing the verse within the narrative of Prophet Yunus (Jonah). Both Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* identify the subject of the verse as Yunus, who faced divine reproach for abandoning his mission prematurely. The "favor from his Lord" refers to Allah’s merciful intervention—swiftly pardoning Yunus after his sincere repentance in the belly of the fish—thereby sparing him the humiliation of being cast "onto the naked shore" in a state of blame. 

Tabatabai underscores the theological principle of *tawfiq* (divine enablement), noting that prophets, though protected from sin (*ismah*), remain subject to human limitations. Yunus’s temporary lapse did not negate his prophetic station but demonstrated the necessity of divine grace to rectify human error. Tabrisi adds that the verse illustrates Allah’s *rahma* (mercy) as an unearned gift, inseparable from His justice: Yunus’s suffering in the fish was both a corrective measure and a means to purify his resolve, aligning with the Shia doctrine that trials purify the believer’s soul. 

The verse also resonates with Shia themes of intercession (*shafa‘a*) and the Ahlul Bayt’s role as channels of divine mercy. As later commentators like Fayd Kashani note, Yunus’s deliverance prefigures the salvific role of the Imams, who mediate Allah’s grace to the faithful. Jurisprudentially, the episode reinforces the obligation of steadfastness (*sabr*) in adversity and the necessity of seeking forgiveness (*istighfar*), principles foundational to Shia spirituality. Thus, the verse encapsulates a core axiom: divine grace sustains creation, but human responsibility—through repentance and adherence to guided leaders—remains indispensable.
49.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars interpret Surah Al-Qalam verse 49 as a profound lesson on divine mercy and human accountability, emphasizing Allah’s intervention in moments of existential crisis. Ayatollah Naser Makarim Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, contextualizes Prophet Yunus’s ordeal as a metaphor for spiritual resilience: even in abandonment—symbolized by being “thrown onto the naked shore”—divine grace (represented by the whale’s protection) emerges when one acknowledges dependence on the Creator. This aligns with modern psychological insights on crisis management, where faith and surrender are increasingly recognized as tools for navigating despair, a theme echoed in Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali’s interfaith dialogues on spiritual resilience in turbulent times.  

Scientifically, marine biologists note parallels between Yunus’s survival in marine ecosystems and humanity’s current climate challenges. The verse’s imagery of vulnerability (“naked shore”) resonates with coastal communities facing rising sea levels, urging ecological stewardship as a form of gratitude for divine favors. Philosophically, scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim link the “censured” state to modern social alienation, where systemic injustice or moral decay leave individuals spiritually stranded—a call to address inequality and nurture communal solidarity.  

Interfaith perspectives highlight shared Abrahamic themes: Jonah’s story in Judeo-Christian traditions similarly underscores redemption through humility. Multiculturally, the verse’s universal message—mercy transcending failure—offers hope in polarized societies, advocating for empathy over condemnation. In an era marked by pandemic recovery and climate anxiety, this verse becomes a timeless reminder: divine grace intercedes not to erase struggle, but to transform it into a catalyst for collective renewal.
49.layer4:
In Surah Al-Qalam verse 49, Allah references Prophet Yunus (عليه السلام) being rescued from his tribulation by divine mercy. The Ahlul Bayt (عليهم السلام) teach that this verse holds profound lessons on divine grace, repentance, and the necessity of clinging to the "rope of Allah" through the guardianship (Wilayah) of the purified Imams. Imam Ali (عليه السلام) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "Allah’s mercy descends where repentance is sought; His pardon is vast, but His justice is precise." This highlights the balance between human responsibility and divine intervention.

The "favor from his Lord" mentioned here is interpreted by Shia scholars as the intercession (Shafa'a) granted through the luminous channel of the Ahlul Bayt. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (عليه السلام) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi* that Yunus’ rescue was tied to his sincere invocation of Allah through the "Names" (Asma ul-Husna) manifested in the Muhammadan Light – a reference to the Imams’ role as divine intermediaries. Without this connection to the divine mercy embodied in the Imamah, even prophets risk spiritual isolation.

Lady Fatimah (عليها السلام) taught that true reliance on Allah means anchoring oneself to His chosen guides. When Yunus acknowledged his error and turned to Allah’s mercy in the depths of darkness, he exemplified the spiritual principle of *tawba nasuh* (sincere repentance) which the Imams emphasize as continuous self-reform through their teachings. Practical guidance from this verse includes:  
1. Cultivating constant awareness of Allah’s encompassing mercy, even in moments of despair.  
2. Seeking proximity to the Ahlul Bayt through daily supplications like Ziyarat Ashura or Dua al-Tawassul.  
3. Embracing repentance not as a single act, but as an ongoing purification process under the Imam’s spiritual guardianship.  

As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (عليه السلام) prays in *Sahifa Sajjadiyya*: "O He Who answers the distressed! Make my soul inseparable from love for Your chosen ones, the gates to Your mercy." This verse reminds us that salvation lies in aligning our spiritual state with the transformative power of Wilayah.

49.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 68:49, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s contextual link to Prophet Yunus (Jonah), his temporary abandonment by the fish, and Allah’s mercy rescuing him from reproach. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir (*Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim*) and Tabari (*Jami al-Bayan*) emphasise Yunus’s hastiness in leaving his people without divine permission, framing his rescue as a testament to Allah’s boundless compassion for repentant servants. Similarly, Shia scholars such as Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) and Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) identify Yunus as the subject, stressing that divine intervention (“a favor from his Lord”) exemplifies Allah’s unwavering commitment to guiding prophets despite human fallibility. Both traditions agree the verse underscores the necessity of divine grace (ni‘mah) transcending human limitations.

Divergent interpretations arise in theological nuances. Sunni scholars like Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam al-Quran*) and Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) focus on Yunus’s *dhamb* (error in judgment), viewing it as a lesson in patience and trust in divine wisdom. They frame the “favor” as Allah’s spontaneous mercy, independent of intermediaries. In contrast, Shia exegetes like Qummi (*Tafsir al-Qummi*) and Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) interpret the “favor” as an expression of Allah’s preordained protection (ʿiṣmah) for prophets, arguing that Yunus’s actions reflected situational urgency rather than moral failing. Tabatabai further links this grace to the broader concept of divine guardianship (wilayah), implicitly connecting prophetic sanctity to the Shia doctrine of Imamah.

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni thought often prioritises individual accountability and Allah’s unilateral mercy, while Shia exegesis integrates prophetic infallibility into a cohesive cosmology of divine guidance. Historically, Shia interpretations emerged within a paradigm emphasising the necessity of infallible leadership (Imams) as extensions of prophetic grace, whereas Sunni readings developed through diverse schools valuing consensus (ijmaʿ) and textual literalism. Both traditions, however, reinforce the verse’s ethical core: human vulnerability to error and the primacy of divine compassion in spiritual redemption. Such interpretations, while theologically distinct, collectively enrich understanding of Quranic teachings on repentance and grace.

50.layer1:
This verse from Surah Al-Qalam refers to Prophet Yunus (Jonah), peace be upon him, after his temporary abandonment of his mission and subsequent repentance. When his people rejected his message, Yunus left them in frustration without awaiting divine permission. After being swallowed by the whale and crying out to Allah in sincere remorse, he was forgiven and spiritually elevated. The phrase *"fa-jtabahu rabbuhu"* (his Lord chose him) highlights Allah’s active selection and purification of Yunus despite his momentary lapse, demonstrating divine mercy. The term *ijtaba* (to choose) implies being singled out for spiritual distinction, while *as-saliheen* (the righteous) denotes those aligned with Allah’s will through submission and moral integrity.  

Classical Shia commentaries, such as those by Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, emphasize that Allah’s choice here is not merely a reward but a transformative act of grace—purifying Yunus’s heart and reintegrating him into the ranks of those who embody steadfastness. This aligns with the Shia understanding that divine guidance intertwines with human responsibility: even prophets, while divinely protected from major error, experience tests that refine their spiritual station.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse offers profound hope. It teaches that sincere repentance and trust in Allah’s mercy can transform mistakes into opportunities for growth. In moments of despair or failure—whether in personal struggles, community challenges, or spiritual dryness—Yunus’s story reminds us that turning to Allah with humility opens doors to redemption. The verse also underscores the value of perseverance: righteousness is not static but a dynamic state nurtured through continuous effort and reliance on divine grace. By internalizing this lesson, believers can approach their shortcomings with courage, knowing Allah’s compassion elevates those who return to Him sincerely.
50.layer2:
In classical Shia exegesis, Surah al-Qalam (68:50) is understood as a profound affirmation of divine grace (lutf) and the transformative power of sincere repentance (tawba) through the narrative of Prophet Yunus (Jonah). The verse follows Yunus’s initial abandonment of his mission and subsequent redemption after being swallowed by the whale, culminating in Allah’s choice (ijtiba) to elevate him among the righteous (al-salihin). As Tabatabai elucidates in *Al-Mizan*, this divine "choosing" (ijtiba) transcends mere forgiveness; it signifies Yunus’s reintegration into the rank of prophetic infallibility (isma) through Allah’s mercy, reaffirming the Shia theological principle that divine guidance rectifies human fallibility when coupled with genuine remorse and submission. 

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* emphasizes that Yunus’s inclusion among the *salihin* reflects his perfected spiritual state post-repentance, aligning him with the divinely guided (mahdiyyin). This aligns with the Shia doctrine that prophets, while protected from major sins (al-kaba’ir), may experience transient lapses (zalla) to exemplify the necessity of tawba—a concept distinct from Sunni interpretations of prophetic infallibility. The verse also underscores the interplay between human agency and divine intervention: Yunus’s sincere supplication (“La ilaha illa Anta,” Quran 21:87) activates Allah’s grace, illustrating the principle that “Allah does not withhold His mercy except from the unrepentant” (as cited in Al-Kulayni’s *Al-Kafi*). 

Theologically, this verse reinforces the Shia view of divine justice (adl), wherein Allah’s selection is neither arbitrary nor detached from human moral striving. Jurisprudentially, it informs the Shia emphasis on tawba as a pillar of spiritual rehabilitation, resonating with Imam Jafar al-Sadiq’s teaching that “repentance effaces what precedes it” (*Bihar al-Anwar*). Thus, the verse serves as both a testament to Allah’s boundless mercy and a paradigm for the believer’s journey from error to rectitude under divine guardianship (wilaya)
50.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qalam’s 50th verse is often framed as a profound testament to divine grace intertwined with human agency. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, highlights how Prophet Yunus’s (Jonah) spiritual rebirth after his trial—being “chosen” by Allah despite his momentary lapse—symbolizes the transformative power of repentance (*tawbah*) and God’s boundless mercy. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali extend this concept to human resilience, noting that divine selection here isn’t passive privilege but a dynamic process requiring active alignment with *salah* (righteousness) through ethical struggle.

Philosophically, this verse resonates with contemporary discussions on redemption and second chances. In a world grappling with systemic inequities and punitive justice models, Yunus’s story offers a paradigm of restorative justice—a theme echoed in Imam Ali’s teachings on compassion over retribution. Socially, it speaks to marginalized communities seeking dignity; as scholar Fatima Haider notes, divine “choosing” transcends societal hierarchies, affirming every individual’s potential for moral elevation when guided by faith and justice.

Scientifically, the narrative parallels psychological insights on post-traumatic growth, where adversity becomes a catalyst for spiritual maturation. Environmentalists like Dr. Seyyed Hossein Nasr also draw ecological lessons: Yunus’s ordeal in the whale’s belly mirrors humanity’s current “entrapment” in ecological crises, urging a return to harmony with creation.

Interfaithly, this verse bridges Abrahamic traditions—Jonah’s story in Judaism and Christianity similarly emphasizes repentance—while inviting multicultural dialogues on ethical resilience. In an era marked by polarization, it underscores a universal truth: redemption is inseparable from humility, accountability, and the courage to transform.
50.layer4:
The verse "And his Lord chose him and made him of the righteous" (68:50) refers to Prophet Yunus (Jonah) being granted divine selection (ijtiba) after his trial. In Shia tafsir, the Ahlul Bayt (as) teach that this "choosing" transcends worldly merit—it is a manifestation of Allah’s all-encompassing mercy and the transformative power of sincere repentance (tawbah). Imam Sadiq (as) states, "Allah’s selection is not for the perfect, but for those whose hearts turn to Him like Yunus in the whale’s belly" (Tafsir al-Qummi). This underscores that divine grace elevates the repentant soul beyond their past errors, aligning them with the "righteous" (salihin) through spiritual rebirth.

Lady Fatimah (as) illuminates this process in her famed sermon: "Allah made faith your purification from polytheism... and obedience to us [Ahlul Bayt] a protection from disunity." Here, the "righteous" are those anchored in the Wilayah of the divine guides. Just as Yunus’s supplication ("La ilaha illa Anta...") in darkness led to his salvation, our adherence to the Imams’ teachings—despite life’s tempests—becomes the vessel for divine selection. Imam Ali (as) explains in Nahj al-Balagha: "Allah chooses whom He wills not by lineage, but by the purity of their secret thoughts."

Practically, this verse urges believers to internalize two truths: First, no soul is beyond redemption if it sincerely turns to Allah through the door of the Ahlul Bayt (as). Second, true "righteousness" is inseparable from allegiance to the Imamah. As Imam Baqir (as) taught, "The salihin are the followers of Ali (as) in every age" (Bihar al-Anwar). Thus, spiritual development lies in emulating the Imams’ patience, humility, and unwavering tawhid—qualities Yunus embodied after his trial. Daily, we must renew our repentance, cling to the Thaqalayn (Quran and Ahlul Bayt), and trust that Allah’s choice transforms the contrite heart into a mirror of His light.

50.layer5:
The verse in question (Q68:50) concerning Prophet Yunus’s divine selection after his trial has been interpreted by both Shia and Sunni scholars with shared emphasis on Allah’s mercy and the transformative power of repentance. Classical commentators across traditions, including Tabari and Tabatabai, concur that Yunus’s repentance after abandoning his mission led to his spiritual elevation. Sunni sources such as Ibn Kathir’s *Tafsir* and Shia works like Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* highlight Yunus’s sincere supplication (Dhun-Nun’s prayer in Q21:87) as the catalyst for divine forgiveness, underscoring a shared theological principle: Allah’s grace responds to human accountability and humility.

Divergences emerge in framing the nature of divine “selection” (ijtaba). Shia exegetes like Qummi and Tabatabai situate Yunus’s redemption within a broader framework of *walaya* (divine guardianship), interpreting his inclusion among the *salihin* (righteous) as inseparable from Allah’s eternal guidance through chosen representatives. Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* posits that Yunus’s spiritual rank was secured through divine intervention transcending his momentary lapse, reflecting the Shia emphasis on Allah’s preordained mercy for His elect. Conversely, Sunni scholars like Qurtubi and Razi stress Yunus’s individual moral agency, with Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* framing his righteousness as a restored state contingent on personal repentance, aligning with Sunni prioritization of individual responsibility in spiritual rehabilitation.

These interpretive nuances reflect distinct theological emphases: Shia tafsir often integrates events into a meta-narrative of divine guidance through the Ahl al-Bayt, while Sunni exegesis prioritizes individual ethical renewal. Historically, these differences stem from early debates about leadership and spiritual authority, though both traditions agree on the verse’s core lesson: divine mercy transcends human error for those who turn to Allah sincerely. The verse’s ethical implication—encouraging repentance and trust in divine grace—remains universally affirmed in religious practice.

50.summary: In classical Shia exegesis, Surah al-Qalam (68:50) is understood as a profound affirmation of divine grace (lutf) and the transformative power of sincere repentance (tawba) through the narrative of Prophet Yunus (Jonah). This verse from Surah Al-Qalam refers to Prophet Yunus (Jonah), peace be upon him, after his temporary abandonment of his mission and subsequent repentance. When his people rejected his message, Yunus left them in frustration without awaiting divine permission. After being swallowed by the whale and crying out to Allah in sincere remorse, he was forgiven and spiritually elevated. Imam Sadiq (as) states, "Allah’s selection is not for the perfect, but for those whose hearts turn to Him like Yunus in the whale’s belly" (Tafsir al-Qummi). believers can approach their shortcomings with courage, knowing Allah’s compassion elevates those who return to Him sincerely.

51.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qalam verse 51, Allah describes the hostile reactions of disbelievers to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) upon hearing the Quran. The phrase *"yuzliqūnaka bi-abṣārihim"* (they would almost make you slip with their eyes) uses the verb *yuzliqūnaka* from the root *z-l-q*, meaning "to cause to slip" or destabilise. This metaphorically illustrates how the disbelievers’ intense, envious gazes—often interpreted as the "evil eye" (*al-‘ayn*)—were aimed at weakening the Prophet’s resolve. Their verbal abuse (*"innahu lamajnūn"*—"he is mad") compounded this psychological attack, seeking to discredit his message.  

Historical accounts note this verse was revealed when Quraysh leaders, threatened by the Quran’s transformative power, escalated their persecution. Scholars like Allamah Tabatabai explain that their hatred manifested through both physical aggression and malicious intent, reflecting a broader pattern of resistance to divine truth. The term *al-dhikr* (the message) emphasises the Quran’s role as a reminder of truth, rejected by those entrenched in arrogance.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse underscores resilience against modern forms of ridicule or hostility faced for upholding Islamic values. Just as the Prophet remained steadfast, believers today are reminded to anchor themselves in faith, trusting Allah’s protection against both overt and subtle opposition—whether through slander, social pressure, or dismissive attitudes toward religious practice. The verse also warns against internalising negativity; like the Prophet, Muslims must respond with dignity, relying on spiritual strength (*tawakkul*) rather than retaliation. By recognising that truth often provokes resistance, this verse invites reflection on patience (*sabr*) and the importance of embodying prophetic courage in daily life.
51.layer2:
In his seminal *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Qalam 51 by emphasizing the psychological and spiritual aggression faced by the Prophet Muhammad (ṣ) from the Quraysh’s elite. The phrase “they would almost make you slip with their eyes” (*yuẓliqūnaka bi-abṣārihim*) is interpreted through two lenses: a literal reading referencing the pre-Islamic belief in the “evil eye” (al-ʿayn), wherein malevolent gazes were thought to inflict harm, and a metaphorical reading denoting the disbelievers’ intense, destabilizing hostility. Tabatabai notes that while the verse acknowledges the psychological weight of such animosity, it simultaneously affirms the Prophet’s divinely guarded resolve (*ʿiṣmah*), as their efforts ultimately failed to “make him slip” from his mission.  

Shaykh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, contextualizes this verse within the broader Meccan rejection of revelation, highlighting the disbelievers’ paradoxical response: their visceral reaction to the Qur’an’s transformative power (*dhikr*) coexisted with accusations of madness. This duality, Tabrisi argues, exposes their cognitive dissonance—unable to refute the Qur’an’s eloquence, they resorted to *ad hominem* attacks. The Shia theological tradition here underscores the epistemic conflict between divinely guided truth (*ḥaqq*) and human arrogance (*istikbār*), a theme recurrent in the struggles of the Ahl al-Bayt (ع) against oppressive powers.  

The verse also resonates with Shia juridical principles regarding the necessity of steadfastness (*thabat*) in confronting persecution, as later exemplified by the Imams. Classical commentators link the disbelievers’ denial to a rejection of *walāyah* (divine guardianship), framing their hostility as a manifestation of spiritual blindness. Thus, the verse transcends its historical context, serving as a perennial reminder of the trials faced by those who uphold divine truth against entrenched ignorance.
51.layer3:
In Surah Al-Qalam verse 51, contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasize the psychological and social dimensions of the disbelievers' hostility toward Prophet Muhammad (PBUH). The verse’s reference to “making you slip with their eyes” is often interpreted through the lens of *ayn al-hasad* (the evil eye), a concept rooted in classical Islamic thought. However, modern scholars such as Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari contextualize this as symbolic of systemic attempts to destabilize truth-tellers through psychological warfare—a phenomenon visible today in online harassment, smear campaigns, and disinformation tactics aimed at discrediting moral leaders.

Scientific studies on the physiological effects of hostility—such as increased cortisol levels from sustained negative attention—resonate with the verse’s imagery. Neuroscientist Dr. Tara Swart’s work on the impact of toxic environments aligns with the idea that sustained malice can erode resilience, mirroring the Prophet’s steadfastness amid persecution. Philosophically, the accusation of madness (*majnun*) reflects a timeless tactic to pathologize dissent, seen today in the stigmatization of activists or whistleblowers as “irrational” or “extremist.”

Globally, this verse speaks to challenges faced by marginalized communities, from Islamophobic rhetoric to the suppression of ethical voices in politics. The Shia perspective, informed by the legacy of Imam Hussain (AS), underscores resistance to such oppression through principled courage. Interfaith parallels exist in the persecution of figures like Gandhi or Martin Luther King Jr., who were similarly vilified. Multiculturally, the verse invites reflection on how societies weaponize labels like “madness” to silence transformative truths, urging solidarity against such dehumanization. In an era of polarized discourse, this verse becomes a call to recognize and counter the corrosive power of collective negativity.
51.layer4:
In Surah Al-Qalam, verse 51, Allah reveals the intense spiritual warfare faced by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) as disbelievers sought to destabilize him through malicious glances and accusations of madness. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this verse unveils a profound reality: envy (*hasad*) and the "evil eye" (*ayn*) are tangible spiritual forces that can harm those disconnected from divine protection. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The eye is a real arrow from Satan’s quiver," emphasizing that envy corrodes the soul of the envier and threatens the envied unless shielded by Allah’s guardianship (*Wilayah*).

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains in *Tafsir al-Burhan* that the disbelievers’ hatred blinded them to the Qur’an’s luminous truth, causing them to project their inner darkness onto the Prophet. Their accusation of madness (*majnun*) reflects a deeper rejection of divine guidance manifest through the Prophet’s infallible (*ma'sum*) heart. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) taught that clinging to the *Ahlul Bayt*’s teachings fortifies believers against such spiritual attacks, saying: "The remembrance of Allah is a light for the heart."

Practically, the Imams advised reciting *Surah al-Falaq* and *Surah al-Nas* daily, seeking refuge in Allah’s perfect names, and cultivating contentment (*rida*) to neutralize envy. True protection lies in embracing the *Wilayah* of the Prophet and his purified progeny, for their spiritual authority (*Imamah*) illuminates the path against all forms of darkness. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught: "The believer’s heart is fortified by the remembrance of Allah; their vision pierces illusions through the light of certainty (*yaqin*)." By aligning one’s soul with the *Ahlul Bayt*’s teachings, believers transform malice into mercy, embodying the Qur’anic truth that "Allah is the Guardian of those who believe" (2:257)

51.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Qalam 68:51, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s historical context: Meccan polytheists’ visceral hostility to Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) upon hearing the Quran’s revelations. Sunni commentators like Tabari and Ibn Kathir emphasise the literal attempt by disbelievers to harm the Prophet through the “evil eye” (ayn), citing pre-Islamic Arabian beliefs about ocular malevolence. Similarly, Shia scholars such as Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) acknowledge this cultural backdrop, with Tabrisi noting the phrase “make you slip with their eyes” metaphorically conveys their intense hatred and psychological warfare against the Prophet’s mission.  

Divergences emerge in theological implications. Sunni works like Qurtubi’s *Al-Jami* and Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* frame the verse as affirming the Prophet’s humanity, wherein divine protection (e.g., “We will protect you,” implied in subsequent verses) shields him from physical or spiritual harm. In contrast, Shia sources like Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* and Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi* emphasise the Prophet’s ontological immunity (ismah) from spiritual vulnerability, interpreting “almost make you slip” as a hyperbolic depiction of disbelievers’ futile malice rather than an actual threat to his infallibility.  

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni thought often prioritises the Prophet’s exemplariness in human struggle, while Shia exegesis underscores his divinely guarded status. Practically, Sunni traditions reinforce seeking refuge (isti‘adhah) from evil eyes, whereas Shia interpretations connect such protection to devotion to the Ahl al-Bayt as inheritors of prophetic sanctity. Historically, Shia emphasis on ismah reflects doctrinal developments around Imamah, while Sunni readings align with their broader narrative-based hermeneutics. Both traditions, however, unite in viewing the verse as a testament to the Quran’s transformative power and the moral resilience of prophetic truth.
